definition: all roads lead to Rome/use different means to obtain the same result (idiom)
pinyin: tiao2 tiao2 da4 lu4 tong1 Luo2 ma3

definition: strip/item/article/clause (of law or treaty)/classifier for long thin things (ribbon, river, road, trousers etc)
strip/item/article/clause (of law or treaty)/classifier for long thin things (ribbon, river, road, trousers etc)
big/huge/large/major/great/wide/deep/older (than)/oldest/eldest/greatly/very much/(dialect) father/father's elder or younger brother
see 大夫[dai4 fu5]
road/CL:條|条[tiao2]/journey/route/line (bus etc)/sort/kind
surname Lu
classifier for an activity, taken in its entirety (tirade of abuse, stint of music playing, bout of drinking etc)
to go through/to know well/(suffix) expert/to connect/to communicate/open/to clear/classifier for letters, telegrams, phone calls etc
gauze/to collect/to gather/to catch/to sift
surname Luo
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]

sentences.english: You should not give up though you failed the exam. All roads lead to Rome.
sentences.chinese: 即使你考試失敗，也不要氣餒，條條大路通羅馬。

sentences.english: They say all roads lead to Rome.
Or, simply said, "All roads lead to Rome", the world is one dollar.
sentences.chinese: 或者簡單說，“條條大路通羅馬”，世界是一元的。

sentences.english: Just as a popular saying goes all roads lead to Rome.
sentences.chinese: 成語“條條大路通羅馬”，就是這個意思。

sentences.english: Let bygones be bygones. Snap out of it, all roads lead to Rome.
sentences.chinese: 過去的就讓他過去吧，別再想了，條條大路通羅馬。

sentences.english: We have the enough reason to believe that all roads lead to Rome.
sentences.chinese: 我們有足夠的理由相信條條大路通羅馬。

definition: to choose what is good and hold fast to it (idiom)
lit. to point at the mulberry tree and curse the locust tree/fig. to scold sb indirectly/to make oblique accusations (idiom)
lit. to share the same bed with different dreams (idiom); ostensible partners with different agendas/strange bedfellows/marital dissension
to tolerate is to nurture an evildoer (idiom); spare the rod and spoil the child
to keep up with the latest fashion
general principle
to convert an enemy into a friend (idiom)
switchboard operator
to force someone to do something
to shoot without aim (idiom); fig. to speak without thinking/firing blindly/to shoot in the air/a shot in the dark
survival of the fittest
to run a newspaper/to publish a newspaper
priority seat (on a bus etc) (Tw)
complete nonsense (idiom)
decline in fortunes
epistemology (in philosophy, the theory of how we know things)
